conclusion: To predict which container (D or E) the liquid will flow into after passing through the baffles, we need to analyze the paths the liquids from A, B, and C take.
Liquid from A (Yellow) flows downward and splits around the brown baffle.
Part of the liquid from A merges with the flow from B and heads towards the center.
The flow from A is directed to the left side due to the orientation of the grey baffle.
The liquid from A ultimately moves towards container D.
Liquid from B (Cyan) flows downward and merges with the yellow liquid from A.
The combined flow of liquids from A and B flows towards the center, but the grey baffle diverts them to the left.
The combined flow of liquids from A and B heads towards container D.
Liquid from C (Orange) flows downward and splits around the light blue baffle.
Part of the liquid from C combines with the flow from B, and part moves towards the right.
The rightward flow of liquid from C is directed by the white baffle towards container E.
Liquids from A and B primarily flow into container D.
Liquid from C flows into container E.
Container D will collect liquids from A and B, and container E will collect liquid from C.
